headline: Big Soft Ginger Cookies
description: This gingerbread cookie recipe is full of molasses and ginger flavor and the cookies stay soft for days! These gingerbread cookies are a holiday favorite.

video.description: See how to make amazing ginger cookies.
video.name: Big Soft Ginger Cookies

name: Big Soft Ginger Cookies

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Set 2 tablespoons sugar in a small bowl; set aside.
Sift together flour, ginger, baking soda, cinnamon, cloves, and salt in a bowl.

Cream margarine and remaining 1 cup sugar in a large bowl until light and fluffy. Beat in egg, then stir in molasses and water. Gradually stir the sifted ingredients into the molasses mixture until well combined.

Use floured hands to shape dough into 24 walnut-sized balls. Roll each ball in the reserved sugar until coated. Place cookies 2 inches apart onto ungreased cookie sheets, and flatten slightly with the bottom of a glass.
Bake in the preheated oven for 8 to 10 minutes, switching racks halfway through.
Remove from the oven and allow cookies to cool on the baking sheets for 5 minutes, then transfer to a wire rack to cool completely.

review.reviewBody: I followed this recipe almost exactly as written & they were fabulous! I used a Gluten-Free flour blend with maybe 1/4 tsp. of xantham gum added to make it more like regular all-purpose flour with the appropriate "chew" for a molasses cookie. I made a couple of different molasses or gingerbread cookies for a taste test for the family, and these were the winners by far. The flavor is excellent, and the texture was perfectly chewy. We preferred them not flattened since they seemed to get better crinkles on top when they hadn't been squashed down. I used a cookie scoop & just dropped the dough ball into a small bowl of sugar & swirled the bowl around the coat the dough. I baked these for exactly 8 minutes. The recipe itself is excellent, and I don't think you'll be disappointed at all if you try it. My only beef--and it's small--is with the video that was made by someone other than the original baker. It shows someone scooping the flour with a measuring cup & then tapping it down on the side of the bowl, rather than spooning flour into the cup & leveling it off. Also, most of the measurements were rounded spoons of things. While it may make for an "aesthetic" look in the video, it can result in cookies that are drier & denser than they ought to be. (& this is especially true in Gluten-Free baking). Skip the video & you'll be just fine.
